prompt_templates.title: AI-Assisted Agent Generation
prompt_templates.prompt:
Create an agent configuration based on this request: "[YOUR DESCRIPTION]"

Requirements:
1. Extract core intent and responsibilities
2. Design expert persona for the domain
3. Create comprehensive system prompt with clear behavioral boundaries, methodologies, edge case handling, and output format
4. Create identifier (lowercase, hyphens, 3-50 chars)
5. Write description with triggering conditions
6. Include 2-3 <example> blocks showing when to use

Return JSON with: {"identifier": "agent-name", "whenToUse": "Use this agent when... Examples: <example>...</example>", "systemPrompt": "You are..."}
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to quickly generate a complete agent configuration from a natural language description

prompt_templates.title: Request Code Review Agent

prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a proactive code quality agent for your plugin

prompt_templates.title: Request Test Generation Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an agent that generates unit tests for code. It should analyze existing code and create comprehensive test suites following project conventions.
prompt_templates.scenario: Building an agent that automatically creates tests for new code

output_examples.input: User asks to create a security analysis agent
output_examples.output: Complete agent markdown file with: name (security-analyzer), description with triggering examples, model (inherit), color (red), tools (["Read", "Grep", "Glob"]), and comprehensive system prompt covering OWASP Top 10 vulnerability analysis

Validation report checking: file existence, frontmatter structure, required fields (name, description, model, color), field formats, system prompt presence and length, example blocks in description - returns pass/fail with specific errors and warnings

best_practices: Include 2-4 concrete triggering examples in description field with context, user message, and commentary
Write system prompts in second person addressing the agent directly ("You are...", "You will...")
Use 'inherit' for model field unless agent requires specific capabilities
Restrict tools to minimum needed following principle of least privilege
Keep agent identifiers 3-50 characters, lowercase with hyphens only
Structure system prompts with: role, core responsibilities, process steps, quality standards, output format, and edge cases
Choose descriptive colors (blue/cyan for analysis, green for generation, red for security, yellow for validation)
Test agent triggering thoroughly with scenarios matching the examples
anti_patterns: Using generic agent names like 'helper' or 'assistant'
Omitting triggering examples from description field
Writing vague descriptions without specific conditions
Writing system prompts in first person ("I am...", "I will...")
Granting unnecessary tool access to agents
Using underscores or special characters in agent identifiers

faq.question: What's the difference between agents and commands in Claude Code plugins?
faq.answer: Agents are autonomous subprocesses for complex, multi-step tasks that operate independently. Commands are user-initiated actions that execute when explicitly called. Use agents for work requiring multiple steps and decision-making, use commands for direct user-triggered actions.

faq.question: How do I make my agent trigger proactively instead of waiting for explicit requests?
faq.answer: Include proactive triggering examples in the description field showing the agent being called after relevant work is completed (e.g., after writing code, before commits). Use commentary to explain why the agent should trigger in these scenarios.

faq.question: What should I set for the model field?
faq.answer: Use 'inherit' (recommended) unless your agent needs specific model capabilities. This makes the agent use the same model as its parent, ensuring consistency. Only use 'sonnet', 'opus', or 'haiku' if you have specific performance or cost requirements.

faq.question: How many triggering examples should I include?
faq.answer: Include 2-4 concrete examples covering: explicit requests, proactive triggering, different phrasings of the same intent, and edge cases. More than 6 examples makes descriptions too long.

faq.question: What tools should I grant my agent access to?
faq.answer: Follow the principle of least privilege - grant only the minimum tools needed. Common sets: read-only analysis ['Read', 'Grep', 'Glob'], code generation ['Read', 'Write', 'Grep'], testing ['Read', 'Bash', 'Grep']. Omit the tools field only if full access is required.

faq.question: How long should my system prompt be?
faq.answer: Aim for 500-3,000 characters for standard agents. Minimum is 20 characters, maximum recommended is 10,000. Include clear structure with responsibilities, process steps, quality standards, output format, and edge cases.
